column1: 10|1_wall_st|Wall Street|A gang of black men labored as long as daylight allowed
column2: digging a three-foot-deep trench from the East River all the way across Manhattan Island to the Hudson River. The trench followed a rough path that ran along the north edge of the village. It was March 1653
column3: and Governor Stuyvesant had been sent orders to fortify New Amsterdam. English warships were gathering in Boston Harbor
column4:
readying to sail south and take the Dutch colony.

The men digging the trench had names such as Paulo d’Angola
column5: Simon Congo
column6: and Anthony Portuguese. As their names showed
column7: many were Africans that had worked aboard Spanish or Portuguese ships before the Dutch seized them. The Africans working were owned by the Dutch West India Company
column8: but some had gained a form of half-freedom. They worked for themselves
column9: but owed the company labor whenever needed. Half-free or enslaved
column10: these Africans could own property
column11: testify in court
column12: bear arms in emergencies
column13: attend church
column14:
and marry. But their children were not free.

When the Africans finished the trench
column15: they formed a wall by standing big logs into it. Each log was 18 inches around and 12 feet long. Then they pounded dirt and stones back into the trench around the base of each log to make the wall strong. They built blockhouses at the ends of the wall
column16: and gates were added where roads ran through it. But as soon as the wall was finished
column17:
it was no longer needed. The Netherlands and England had signed a peace treaty. But the wall built by the Africans gave the rough path that became a street a new name—Wall Street.


|The wall became Wall Street
column18: which is now the financial capital of the world. Up until the Civil War and long after slavery in New York was illegal
column19: Wall Street firms profited from the slave trade.|In 1653
column20: Africans built a wall across Manhattan in order to protect New Amsterdam from the English.  You can see a plaque about the wall on the Bank of New York at One Wall Street.|1653-12-17 15:29:00||40.707726|-74.011665|24||24|24|10

column1: 13|african_free_school|The African Free School|Soon after the Revolution
column3: a group of wealthy
column4: powerful white men formed the New York Manumission Society. Although many were slave owners
column5: their mission was to aid the enslaved
column6: and to gradually end slavery in the state. As part of their efforts
column7: they opened the African Free School in 1788
column8: where the children of both free and enslaved blacks were taught reading
column9: writing
column10: arithmetic
column11: and geography. The boys also studied astronomy
column12: a skill needed by seamen
column13: and the girls learned sewing and knitting. The school had many visitors—especially on examination days when students could show off their work to outsiders. In this way
column14:
they could prove to doubting New Yorkers that black students were "not inferior to those of fairer complexions…in acquiring a knowledge of Letters."

The school began with about 40 students in one room. In the 1820s
column15: as the date of freedom for New York’s slaves drew near
column16: the enrollment grew to 800 students. By 1834
column17: when the African Free schools were absorbed into the New York public school system
column18: over 1
column19:
400 students were enrolled in seven school buildings.

Many of the students of the African Free School went on to become community leaders. James McCune Smith became the first African American licensed doctor
column20: Henry Highland Garnett was a leading abolitionist and the first African American to address Congress
column21: and Ira Aldridge became the most famous African American actor of his day. As students these men had learned the art of public speaking. As adults
column22: many used that skill to speak out for freedom
column24:
and equality for their race.
|African Free School #2 was located at 135-137 Mulberry Street in the neighborhood then known as Five Points. All together
column25: there were at least seven African Free Schools in the city.|This picture of African Free School #2 is based on a drawing by one of its students named Patrick Reason. He
column26: like many of his fellow students

column1: 21|african_society_for_mutual_relief|African Society for Mutual Relief|As soon as it was legal for black New Yorkers to organize
column2: they did so. In 1808
column3: the African Society for Mutual Relief was founded. (The Society may have met in secret earlier
column4: but there are no records to prove it.) At that time
column5: black children could not go to white schools. If their parents died
column6: white orphanages were closed to them. Insurance companies would not sell policies to African Americans. Even graveyards were segregated. As a result
column7: the Society formed a much-needed safety net for African American families and small businesses. Members’ dues paid for burial costs and a form of health insurance. If a member died
column8:
their widow and children received help.

In 1810
column9:
the New York Legislature granted their petition and the Society became the first incorporated African American association. Members celebrated the event with a parade and took to the streets carrying silk banners and signs. The association grew quickly.

In the beginning money was short
column10: but in 1820 a former Haitian slave named Juliet Toussaint donated enough money for a plot of land and a meetinghouse at 42 Baxter Street (called Orange Street then). Located in the Five Points neighborhood
column11: the African Hall for Mutual Relief became an important meeting place
column12: a school
column13: and a stop on the Underground Railroad. It was also a target. In the anti-abolitionist riot of 1834
column14: a white mob attacked the Hall
column15: breaking all the windows and wrecking the place. But the society survived that riot
column16: as well as the draft riot of 1863
column17: and lasted until 1945.|The New York African Society for Mutual Relief at 42 Baxter Street was targeted in two riots in the 1800s. It later moved uptown and survived until 1945.|Juliet Toussaint
column18: a member of the growing Haitian community in New York
column19: donated money for the African Hall for Mutual Relief in 1820. The hall was located at 42 Baxter Street.|1808-12-17 15:29:00|1945-12-17 15:29:00|40.715565|-74.000572|29||29|29|21

column1:
3|african_grove_theater|African Grove Theater|

On Mercer Street in the fall of 1821
column2: King Lear limped out onto stage
column3: and the audience went wild. Lear was black. The event was the first play staged by the first black theatrical producer
column4:
who had formed the first black theater company that went on to perform the first play written by an African American in the first black theater in the country.  The genius behind it all was William Alexander Brown.

His venture began back in 1816 in a place Brown called The African Grove. During the summer
column5: white New Yorkers enjoyed private “tea” gardens that offered ice cream treats
column6: cold drinks
column7: music
column8: dramatic readings
column9: and conversation. According to the papers
column10: Brown opened the first tea garden to “which the sable race could find admission and refreshment.” It was a great success and led Brown to build the 300-seat theater on Mercer Street. Here his company staged popular versions of Shakespeare’s Richard the III and Othello. They also presented original works such as King Shotaway
column11:
a play written by Brown about a black Carib revolt in the Caribbean.

But the African American theater was an annoyance to the Park Theater nearby. Stephen Price
column12: the producer of the Park
column13: hired white rowdies to yell and “riot” at the African Grove. When the neighbors (including Price) complained
column14:
the police shut the theater down. The African Grove became a mobile theater for several years before closing its doors.

|The first African Grove Theater was located on Mercer Street near Houston. It was built on the second floor of a two-story house with a large tea garden in back.|James Hewlett (1778-1836) was the star performer at the African Grove Theater. As a youngster
column15: Ira Aldridge
column16: the greatest black actor of the 19th century
column17: probably got his start here

column1: 2|black_brigades|The Black Brigades|During the Revolution
column2: at least 80
column3: 000 African Americans declared their own independence—and fled. The British had promised freedom to any slave who left a rebel master (but not a loyal one) and made it to British lines. Harry Washington
column4: whose owner was the patriot General George Washington
column5: was one of 800 who reached British lines in Virginia. He fought for “Liberty to Slaves” in an all-black regiment
column6: and when the British left that colony for New York
column7:
he went with them.

By 1780
column8: there were more than 10
column9: 000 blacks living in a British-occupied New York. Many lived in a “canvas city” of shanties and tents that sprang up between Broadway and the Hudson River. The area had been burned to the ground when the patriots abandoned the city. Blacks who fought with the British
column10: like Harry Washington
column11: lived in “Negro barracks” at 18 Broadway
column12: 10 Church Street
column13: and elsewhere. These men fought in units known as the Black Pioneers and the Black Brigade. Most did the hard support work the army needed
column14:
but some were armed and fought. The most famous Black Pioneer was Colonel Tye who led 800 men in a guerrilla war against the patriots in Staten Island and New Jersey.

When peace came
column15: so did the slave hunters. In 1783
column16: they roamed the city
column17: seizing blacks from the streets and even from their beds. But much to General Washington’s dismay
column18: the British refused to return those slaves that had been promised freedom. Instead
column19: their names were written in the “The Book of Negroes
column20: ” and some 3
column21:
000 free African Americans climbed aboard British ships and sailed away. Harry Washington would eventually reach a place in Africa not far from where he was born.

|During the Revolution
column22: many members of the Black Brigades or Black Pioneers who fought with the British lived in “Negro barracks” at 10 Church Street and elsewhere.|The handwritten “Book of Negroes” lists the names of some 3
column23: 000 African Americans who left New York City with the British. The book is located in the National Archives in Washington

column1: 31|bridge_street_awme_church|Bridge Street AWME Church|It was October 1865
column2: only months after the last shots of the Civil War were fired. People in Brooklyn opened their newspaper
column3: the Brooklyn Eagle
column4: to learn that “Last evening an immense congregation
column5: fully half consisting of whites
column6: was present at the African M. E. Church in Bridge street.” What brought so many white people to the black church? Harriet Tubman
column7: the most famous “conductor” on the Underground Railroad
column8: was speaking. Moses
column9: as she was called
column10: was in a familiar place. Before the Civil War she had led some 300 enslaved men
column11: women
column12:
and children to freedom by hiding in “stations” such as the Bridge Street Church during the day and traveling at night.

The original church
column13: known as the Sand Street Methodist Episcopal Church
column14: was founded by a British army captain in 1766. He first led open-air services for a congregation of blacks
column15: whites
column16: and Indians near the banks of the East River. The congregation grew and the church moved indoors. Unfortunately
column17: racism eventually developed
column18:
and the African Americans were first segregated and then barred from the altar and charged a fee for worshiping.

The black worshipers broke away in 1816 and organized the African Methodist Episcopal Church on High Street. Later
column19: when it moved
column20: it was called the Bridge Street Church. The congregation could claim many firsts. They had the first black church in Brooklyn. It was located in Weeksville
column21: one of the first black communities in the city. And in 1827
column22:
the congregation opened Brooklyn’s first school for black children.


|Today the Bridge Street AWME Church is located at 277 Stuyvesant Avenue
column23:
where it continues to attract many new parishioners from Africa and Latin America.
|Runaway slaves were once hidden in the basement of the Bridge Street Church at 311 Bridge Street. Today the site is the Student Center of Polytechnic University.
|1766-12-17 15:29:00|1865-12-17 15:29:00|40.694324|-73.985168|1||1|1|31

column1:
28|catherine_ferguson|Catherine Ferguson|Catherine (“Katy”) Ferguson was born in 1779 with almost nothing—not even freedom. Her mother was sold away when she was 8 years old. That was when Katy became determined to gain her freedom and to make the world a better place. She did both.

First she wanted to learn to read. Her mistress said she was too smart already—smarter than her own children — and refused her. At the age of 10 she asked her master for her freedom
column2:
promising to live a life serving God. He refused her. At 16 she found a woman who agreed to purchase her freedom for $200 if Katy would repay her. It took Katy 11 months of work to pay $100 back; then someone in her church paid the remaining debt. Katy was finally free.

To make a living she made wedding cakes
column3: the best in town. The rest of the time she helped others. She began to take children in off the street on Sundays and got others to teach them to read the bible.  When her minister heard what she was doing
column4:
he offered to move the group to the basement of his church. Some say this was the first Sunday school in the city.

Katy also took in a total of 48 needy children
column5: 20 of them white. She cared for them
column6: fed them
column7: and found them all good homes. When Ferguson died
column8: the newspapers wrote
column9: “Thousands in this community have heard of or known Katy Ferguson…the celebrated cake-maker for weddings and other social parties. But many…may be ignorant of the… extraordinary good deeds which crowned her life.” The reporter also said that wherever Katy lived
column10:
the whole neighborhood became a better place for it.
|Children
column11: both black and white
column12:
came to Ferguson’s home at 51 Warren Street to learn to read the bible. Some say this was the first Sunday school in New York City.
|Catherine Ferguson
column13: or “Katy” as she was called
column14:
was determined from the age of 8 to gain her freedom and make the world a better place. She did both.
|1779-12-17 15:29:00|1855-12-17 15:29:00|40.714657|-74.009094|14||14|14|28

column1: 1|david_ruggles_home|David Ruggles Home|David Ruggles might have been the most hated activist of his day. One slave catcher screamed that he would give “a thousand dollars if I had …Ruggles in my hands as he is the leader.” And Ruggles was just that—a leader against slavery. He came to New York around 1827 from Connecticut
column2: where he was born free. When he arrived he was 17 years old—and fearless
column3: determined
column4:
and educated.

The year 1827 was a time of parades celebrating the end of slavery in New York. More and more runaways were arriving from the South every day. But right behind them were the slave catchers. Called “blackbirders
column5:
” they roamed the streets looking to reclaim some of the runaways and even to kidnap free blacks. No black person was safe. Ruggles saw how dangerous the city was and decided to do something about it.

In 1835
column6: he and several other young black activists founded the New York Committee of Vigilance. Ruggles and the rest of the Committee protected runaways and confronted the slave catchers. He made the city government grant jury trials to slaves who were recaptured
column7: and he obtained lawyers for them. He personally helped as many as 600 fugitives
column8: including the now-famous Frederick Douglass. He also ran an antislavery bookstore until it was destroyed by a mob. In addition
column9: he wrote hundreds of articles. He bought a printing press and published his own pamphlets and a magazine called Mirror of Liberty. It was the first periodical published by a black American. But after 20 years of activism
column10: Ruggles was nearly blind and seriously ill. Many
column11: including Frederick Douglass
column12:
came to his aid. Ruggles died in Massachusetts in 1849.
|Ruggles sheltered runaway Frederick Douglass here at 36 Lispenard Street. He also ran a boarding house at 67 Lispenard that was a meeting place for abolitionists.|David Ruggles was the leading
column13: and possibly the most hated
column14: abolitionist in New York City. His courage
column15: activism
column16: and writings made the city a safer place for fugitives and free blacks.|1827-12-17 15:29:00|1849-12-17 15:29:00|40.71999|-74.003845|8||8|8|1

column1:
16|downing-s_oyster_house|Downing’s Oyster House|Downing’s Oyster House

Before New York was called the Big Apple
column2: it could have been called the Big Oyster. New York was famous for its oysters. And Thomas Downing
column3: a free black man
column4: owned the most famous oyster house of all. Bankers
column5: politicians
column6: stockbrokers
column7: lawyers
column8: businessmen
column9: and socialites flocked to Downing’s Oyster House to eat raw
column10: fried
column11: or stewed oysters
column12: oyster pie
column13: fish with oyster sauce
column14: or poached turkey stuffed with oysters. As the crowd of power brokers ate and made deals under the chandeliers
column15: Thomas’s son George lead escaping slaves to the basement. There they were safe from the “blackbirders
column16: ” or bounty hunters
column17:
that were roaming the streets in search of runaways.

From 1825 to 1860
column18: Thomas
column19: and his son George T. Downing were part of the Underground Railroad to Canada and freedom. They were also leaders in the growing abolitionist movement. In 1836
column20: Thomas helped found the all-black United Anti-Slavery Society of the City of New York. The next year he began petitioning New York State for equal suffrage for black men. He took one petition after another to Albany. "If one petition failed
column21: another would be presented
column22: " he said. When not a single high school in the city would accept African American students
column23: he helped found the first schools that would accept them. According to his son
column24:
Thomas Downing was an "extremely active" man who "knew not tire."

When Thomas Downing died on April 10
column26: the New York Chamber of Commerce closed for the day out of respect.|Downing’s Oyster House was located at 5 Broad Street
column28: where fresh oysters were stored and escaping slaves were hidden
column31:
and 7 Broad Street.|Thomas Downing rowed out to the boats to pick over the oysters before the ships reached the oyster barges along the East River. Downing’s Oyster House served only the best.
|1825-12-17 15:29:00|1860-12-17 15:29:00|40.706951|-74.010765|13||13|13|16

column1: 27|five_points|Five Points|Five Points was a neighborhood around the intersection of Worth Street
column2: Baxter Street
column3: and Cross Street
column4: which no longer exists. It became a world-famous slum in the 1840s. In colonial times
column5: however
column6: it was a quiet place north of the city that included a pond
column7: marshes
column8:
and a hill that overlooked it all. Africans buried their dead near the pond and lived nearby in a large area called “Land of the Blacks.”

By the early 1800s
column9: however
column10: the city was growing and housing was needed. The hill was removed and its earth
column11: along with garbage
column12: dumped into the pond. Homes and businesses were built on this landfill
column13: but the ground was soft and damp; the houses soon began to rot and topple
column14: and the unpaved streets turned to mud. As the housing decayed
column15:
New York’s first slum was born. Poor Irish and German immigrants moved in to live alongside the African Americans there.

The neighborhood became famous for crime and disease. But
column16: more happily
column17:
it was also known for dance. Competitions between Irish and black musicians and dancers helped to invent a brand new dance form called tap dance.

Five Points was also where many abolitionist organizations were located. There was the Chatham Chapel
column18: where black and white abolitionists met
column19: and the African American Mutual Relief Hall. Churches such St. Philip’s African Episcopal Church and the African Bethlehem Church were part of the Underground Railroad
column20: as were many of the homes in the area. Five Points was a dangerous neighborhood
column21:
but it was also a safe haven for those fleeing slavery.



|Five Points got its name from 5 corners where Anthony (now Worth) Street
column23:
and Cross Street (which no longer exists) met.
|In the 1830s
column24: free blacks and Irish and German immigrants lived crowded together in Five Points. “The most dangerous place in the city” was also a safe haven for those escaping slavery.|1800-12-17 15:29:00|1859-12-17 15:29:00|40.714359|-74.00045|15||15|15|27

column1: 6|execution_grounds|The Execution Grounds|The year 1741 started out badly. Poor whites and blacks lived in fear of freezing or starving to death. There were food shortages and the winter set records as the coldest known. And then there were fires. First the governor’s house in Fort George burned to the ground. Then there were four fires in one day. People panicked
column2: thinking it was a slave uprising—their worst fear.  Africans were one-fifth of the community’s population
column3: and there had been violent uprisings in the past and in other places. A hunt for the conspirators began
column4:
as more fires were set.

In this climate of hysteria
column5: a grand jury quickly agreed that there was a plot to burn the city and kill its inhabitants. It was thought that there were ringleaders and that they must be white. The first arrested
column6: mostly black men and a few whites
column7: were thrown into jail in the basement of City Hall
column8: where they were questioned and probably beaten. Large rewards
column9: including freedom from indenture
column10: were offered to any who would give evidence. An indentured servant named Mary Burton was the first to name names. She described a great plot
column11:
led by white ringleaders. This was just what the investigators wanted to hear. Soon others agreed to give names. It was not long before 160 black and 21 white men and women were arrested in “The Great Negro Plot.”

At trial the accused had no legal representation. All the lawyers were working for the prosecution. At least 34 people were convicted and brought to the Execution Grounds. Seventeen blacks were hanged
column12:
as well as four white “ringleaders.” Thirteen Africans were burned at the stake. The events were remembered as the “Bonfires of the Negroes.” An additional 70 enslaved African Americans were shipped to the Caribbean and sold.
|What was the execution grounds in 1741 is now Foley Square
column13: located between Lafayette and Centre Streets. The four white people convicted in the plot were hung near the East River.|During the hysteria of the “Great Negro Plot
column14: ” 17 African Americans were hung and 13 were burned at the stake. The execution grounds were located on the African Burial Ground.|1741-12-17 15:29:00|2007-12-18 10:41:00|40.71434|-74.002632|18||18|18|6

column1: 8|fort_amsterdam|Fort Amsterdam|Fort Amsterdam was designed to be a state-of-the-art diamond-shaped fort
column2: built of stone and bristling with cannon. The designer warned against building it in haste. However
column4: the town was in desperate need of houses
column5: so a much simpler fort was planned. It would be roughly a square of four simple brick walls
column6:
mounded over with dirt.

To build the fort
column7: Peter Minuit needed laborers
column8: and in 1626 he got just what he needed. The Dutch West India Company sent the first African “bondsmen” to New Amsterdam. Some of their names described their origins: Antony Congo
column9: Paulo d’Angola
column10: Pieter San Tomé
column11: Anthony the Portuguese
column12: Jan Fort Orange. Many of the men had been captured from Spanish or Portuguese ships. They were experienced seamen who already understood some European languages
column13: religions
column14:
and laws.

For 10 years the men worked to build the fort. They dug up tree stumps
column15: hauled dirt
column16: mounded it up over the fort walls
column17: and battered it down firmly. Finally
column18: the Africans covered the earthen walls of the fort with sod. But as soon as it was finished
column19: the fort began to crumble. The settlers didn’t usually fence their animals
column20: so goats
column21: sheep
column22: and cattle strayed onto the weedy slopes to graze. Pigs went there to dig or rout in the dirt walls. In the words of one settler
column23: the fort soon looked “like a molehill or a tottering wall.” But the Africans were busy elsewhere. They had to dig ditches
column29: and load the Company’s ships with thousands of pelts of beaver
column32:
and wildcat.



|The site of Fort Amsterdam
column33: once used as a refuge for white settlers from Native Americans
column34:
is now occupied by the Museum of the American Indian.

|This picture shows Fort Amsterdam
column35: and the Dutch Church built within it
column36:
behind a row of houses. On the shore you can see the company weighing beam and a tall crane used to unload cargo.
|1626-12-17 15:29:00||40.704914|-74.014008|17||17|17|8

column1: 29|fraunces_tavern|Fraunces Tavern|Around the time of the American Revolution
column2: everyone in New York knew Samuel Fraunces. He ran the best tavern in town
column3: supported the patriot cause
column4: and was a trusted aid to George Washington himself. His daughter
column5: Phoebe
column6: once saved the General’s life when she foiled a plot to poison him. But today little is known about Samuel Fraunces—even his race is a bit of a mystery. He was called “Black Sam
column7: ” but he was
column8: and still is
column9: described as being white
column10: Negro
column11: “colored
column12: ” Haitian
column13:
and mulatto.

Samuel Fraunces came to New York City from the Caribbean and in 1762 opened what is now called Fraunces Tavern. From the start his tavern was famous for its great food and fine wines
column14: but today Fraunces Tavern is known for the history that was made there: It’s where New York’s Sons of Liberty met and planned their own Boston-style tea party. After the group dumped English tea in the harbor
column15: the British occupied the city
column16: and Samuel Fraunces moved his family to safety in New Jersey. Then he signed up as a patriot soldier and fought with George Washington. He also spied for the patriot cause
column17: gave money
column18: and housed and fed American soldiers and prisoners. When the British finally sailed away
column19: a great celebration in honor of “Evacuation Day” was held in the Fraunces Tavern. A week later
column20:
Washington made a famous farewell speech to his officers there.

After the war Washington thanked Fraunces for giving so much “…to the cause of our country and its independence and freedom
column21:
” and Congress sent him a letter citing both his generous support of American prisoners and his secret service during the war. Samuel Fraunces died in 1795.
|Today Fraunces Tavern is a museum operated by the Sons of the Revolution. Built in 1719 as an elegant home
column22:
the building is one of the oldest standing in Manhattan.
|Samuel Fraunces
column24: ” bought 54 Pearl Street for a tavern in 1762. Well known in its day

column1:
15|freedom-s_journal|Freedom’s Journal|

Before 1827
column2: blacks didn’t exist in the newspapers
column3: unless they committed a crime. African American weddings
column4: births
column5: deaths
column6: and accomplishments were not to be found in a newspaper anywhere in the United States. But the year 1827 saw big changes. New York finally abolished slavery
column7: and two young black men
column8: John Brown Russwurm and Samuel E. Cornish
column9:
founded Freedom’s Journal. It was the first African American owned and operated newspaper in the country.

For most of the black community
column10: reading came only after freedom
column11: since it had been forbidden under slavery. To read black voices for the first time was powerful. On the front page of the new paper the editors wrote: “We wish to plead our own cause. Too long have others spoken for us.” Inside were stories about slavery
column12: lynchings
column13: and social justice. The paper also covered international news of special interest to the community
column14: such as events in Haiti and Sierra Leone. In addition
column15: the paper featured biographies of black men and women
column16: schools
column17: jobs
column18: and housing opportunities. It also listed weddings
column19: births
column20:
and deaths.

For two years Freedom’s Journal served a community of 300
column21: 000 African Americans in the North. It was sent to 11 states and the District of Columbia
column24:
and Canada. It was followed by no less than 24 other black newspapers in the years before the Civil War.

|The offices for Freedom’s Journal moved around. This location is 236 Church Street. Another office was located at 152 Church Street a few blocks farther downtown.|Samuel E. Cornish
column28:
founded the nation’s first black newspaper in 1827. They called it Freedom’s Journal.

|1827-12-17 15:29:00|1829-12-17 15:29:00|40.717354|-74.006065|19||19|19|15

column1: 4|hughson-s_tavern|Hughson's Tavern|In the spring of 1741
column2: all eyes were on a tavern at the corner of Liberty and Trinity Streets. The tavern was on the waterfront then
column3:
and it was a meeting place for free and enslaved blacks as well as poor whites. It was illegal in those days for more than three slaves to meet unless they were working.

Trouble began after a burglary. The man charged with the crime was a slave called Caesar. When he was arrested at Hughson’s Tavern
column4: investigators thought that John Hughson and his wife Sarah (who were white) were trading in stolen goods. Mary Burton
column5:
Hughson’s
16-year-old servant
column6: was brought in for questioning. The investigators offered her a choice: She could tell all that she “knew” and gain freedom from being a servant
column7: or go to prison. She chose the first option
column8: and the Hughsons were quickly arrested. Then fires broke out—once there were four in one day. New Yorkers panicked
column9: fearing the worst—another slave uprising. Again investigators turned to Mary Burton
column10:
and she again told them what they wanted to hear.

Mary claimed that Hughson’s Tavern was a meeting place for blacks and whites plotting to burn the city
column11: murder its inhabitants
column12: and seize power. The slaves would become masters
column13: she said
column14: and Caesar
column15: the thief
column16: would become governor. Her story was incredible
column17: but it was believed. In the hysteria of “The Great Negro Plot” almost half of the adult black male population was arrested and brought to trial. In the end
column18: 17 blacks were hanged
column19: as well as the Hughsons and 2 other whites. Thirteen Africans were burned at the stake
column20:
and 70 enslaved blacks were shipped to the Caribbean to be resold.



|Today
column21: the site of Hughson’s Tavern at the corner of Liberty and Trinity Streets is far from the waterfront. What was once the location of docks for ships is now the site of the former World Trade Center.|Hughson’s Tavern was on the waterfront in 1741. Its doors were open to blacks and poor whites

column1: 17|james_mccune_smith_pharmacy|James McCune Smith Pharmacy|In 1824
column2:
the aged Revolutionary War hero General Lafayette returned to America for a tour of the nation he had helped to forge. While in New York he asked to visit the African Free School. James McCune Smith was chosen to write and deliver the welcoming address. Smith was 11 years old.

Smith was a brilliant student who wanted to become a doctor. But there were no licensed black doctors in America then
column3: so he was apprenticed to a blacksmith instead. As Smith worked the blacksmith’s bellows with one hand
column4:
he held a Latin grammar in the other and continued to study. But when he applied to Columbia College (called Kings College then) he was turned down. So instead he went to one of the world’s top medical schools in Great Britain. In five years he earned three degrees and graduated at the top of his class.

Upon his return to New York he opened a pharmacy at 93 West Broadway in 1837. Here he served both white and black patients in the front of the store. In the back
column5: he met with fellow activists and conspired to end slavery in the South
column6: to win the vote for blacks in New York
column7: and to educate black youth. Together with abolitionists such as Frederick Douglass
column8: Gerrit Smith
column9: and John Brown
column10: he helped found the Radical Abolitionist Party. As the son of a self-emancipated mother
column11: his pharmacy was a place where many escaping slaves found help. James McCune Smith worked for economic and social justice until his death in 1865
column12:
just a few weeks after passage of the Thirteenth Amendment. 
|The pharmacy of Dr. McCune Smith was located at 93 West Broadway. Many of the leading abolitionists and activists of the time met in his library in a back room.

|Dr. James McCune Smith was the first licensed African American doctor in the country. This portrait was created by Patrick Reason

column1: 12|john_street_church|John Street Church|At the opening of the John Street Methodist Church
column2: the priest addressed "those in the gallery
column3: " welcoming the African Americans. The segregated black worshipers could cook the food
column4: clean the homes
column5: and care for the children of the white worshipers
column6: but they could not pray together with them. In other churches
column7: the segregation was far worse. Some churches had “hidden galleries
column8: ” small closed rooms out of sight. Other churches had “negro pews” in corners or over stairways. Black parishioners could not vote or preach
column9:
but they could offer their services in the form of labor.

At the John Street Church
column10: African Peter Williams was a sexton. He probably dug the graves
column11: swept the church
column12: and kept up the grounds. James Varick was a deacon
column13:
a church officer who probably helped the priest give communion to the black worshipers—only after the whites had received communion.

Williams and Varick had attended the church since it was founded in 1766. This was a time of change. During the Revolution
column14: British soldiers occupied the city.  After that
column15: General George Washington came to reclaim the city and the slaves that had fled to the British there. But the church’s practice of segregation remained the same. Williams
column16: Varick
column17: and other black worshipers began to hold separate meetings. Then the group decided to form a separate church. In October of 1800
column18:
the African Methodist Episcopal Church at the corner of Church and Leonard Streets was dedicated. It would become an enduring place of worship and struggle.

|Today the John Street Church is still located at 44 John Street. It includes the Wesley Chapel Museum
column19: which tells the story of the “The Oldest Methodist Congregation in America.”|The John Street Church welcomed Peter Williams and other African worshipers
column20: but blacks and whites were segregated. In the early 1800s
column21: a group separated to form the first black church in the state.|1766-12-17 15:29:00|1800-12-17 15:29:00|40.709232|-74.008041|2||2|2|12

column1:
18|mother_ame_zion_church|Mother AME Zion Church|

In the late 1700s
column2: the Methodists of the mostly white John Street Church welcomed Africans and their descendents
column3: and many came to worship there. Peter Williams
column4: born a slave
column5: became a sexton and James Varick became a deacon of the church. In time
column6: however
column7: the worshipers in the Negro pews grew frustrated. They wanted to speak out against slavery and to worship as equals. Finally
column9: James Varick led a group of about 100 worshipers to an old rented building on Cross Street to worship separately. This congregation would found the Mother African Methodist Episcopal Zion Church
column10:
the first black church in the state.

By 1800
column11: the group moved into a small wooden building at the corner of Church and Leonard Streets. The church thrived
column12: and by 1820
column13: Mother Zion had a new brick building. That same year the leaders voted to leave the White Methodist Episcopal Church because it would not ordain black bishops. James Varick became the first Bishop of the new church. It was a time when more and more black New Yorkers were gaining their freedom. These newly free African Americans were determined to end slavery in the South and racism in the North. The AME Church played a big part in the activism of that time. It was a stop on the Underground Railroad and many who worshiped there
column14: such as Frederick Douglass and Sojourner Truth
column15:
became leaders and abolitionists.

As African Americans moved uptown
column16:
so did the church. Today Mother AME Zion Church is located at 140-7 W. 137th Street in Harlem.

|The present Mother AME Zion Church is located at 140-7 W. 137th Street. The building was designed by George W. Foster
column17: Jr.
column18: one of the first black architects to be licensed in the U.S.|The first black church in the state was the Mother AME Zion Church located at 158 Church Street. James Varick was its first bishop.|1796-12-17 15:29:00|1820-12-17 15:29:00|40.714962|-74.007935|11||11|11|18

column1: 19|pierre_toussaint|Pierre Toussaint|In 1996
column2: Pope John Paul II bestowed the title of “Venerable” on Pierre Toussaint. Two years later
column3: Pierre Toussaint Square was named for him. This man
column4: who was brought to New York as a slave in 1787
column5:
may soon become the first Haitian saint.

Toussaint was raised as a slave in the household of Jean Berard
column6: a family of devout Catholics who taught him both reading and writing. When the family fled the revolution on their island
column7: they brought Pierre and his sister Rosalie with them. Pierre was immediately apprenticed to a hairdresser
column8: and went on to become one of the best in the city. At that time
column9: wealthy women would spend $1000 a year on their hairdos
column10:
so Toussaint was able to make very good money. But what he did with his money is more extraordinary.

When his master died
column11: Toussaint supported his mistress. He bought his sister’s freedom rather than his own
column12: so that she could marry and bear free children. He bought his future wife’s freedom and helped many other slaves to buy theirs. He donated money to his beloved Church
column13: to ministers and nuns
column14: to orphans white and black
column15: and to countless other causes. Not only did he donate money
column16:
but he also visited the sick and nursed them during yellow fever epidemics when no one else dared to.

Upon his death in 1853
column17: the city mourned him
column18: the papers eulogized him
column19: and the great Revolutionary leader General Philip Schuyler said of him
column20:
“I have known Christians who were not gentlemen or gentlemen who were not Christians--but one man I know who is both--and that man is Black.”

|In 1953
column21: this marker was laid in Toussaint’s honor at St. Patrick’s Old Cathedral on Mott Street. His remains were later moved to the crypt below the altar of the current St. Patrick’s Cathedral.|Pierre Toussaint and his wife Juliette Noel Toussaint lived in a comfortable home on Franklin Street and attended services nearby at St. Peter’s Church at 16 Barclay Street.|1787-12-17 15:29:00|1853-12-17 15:29:00|40.723679|-73.995552|7||6|7|19

column1: 14|seneca_village|Seneca Village |As a community of free black property owners
column2: Seneca Village was unique in its day. Located in the hilly
column3: rock-strewn woods between present-day 82nd and 89th Streets and 7th and 8th Avenues
column4: at the time it was a long walk to the crowded city. The village grew steadily from 1825
column5: when Andrew Williams first bought three lots for $125. By 1832
column6: about 25 more lots were sold to African Americans. And by the early 1850s
column7: the village boasted three churches
column8: a school
column9: and a population of some 300 people. Over the years
column10: German and Irish immigrants joined the community. This diverse community lived in peace
column11:
attending the All Angel’s Church together and sharing the services of one midwife.

But as the city pushed north
column12: the media began to paint a different picture of the little village
column13: calling it a “shantytown” and calling the property owners “squatters” who were “wretched and debased.” Many people in the city
column14: including Mayor Fernando Wood
column15: wanted the land for a great new park. In 1855
column16: the mayor used the power of eminent domain to claim the land. Then he sent the police to clear it. For two years the residents resisted the police as they petitioned the courts to save their homes
column17: churches
column18: and schools. In 1857
column19: they were finally removed. As one newspaper put it
column20:
the raid upon Seneca Village would “not be forgotten…[as] many a brilliant and stirring fight was had during the campaign. But the supremacy of the law was upheld by the policeman’s bludgeons.”




|Today
column21: as you walk in Central Park near West Drive and 85th Street
column22: you can see a plaque commemorating Seneca Village.|Seneca Village thrived as a largely black community from 1825 to 1855

column1: 30|sojourner_truth|Sojourner Truth|In 1797
column2: a baby girl named Isabella was born in upstate New York. Her parents were Elizabeth and James Baumfree
column3: but she was the property of their Dutch master
column4: who sold her off at the age of 9. By the time she was 12
column5: she had been sold two more times. When slavery was outlawed in New York
column6: Isabella was 30 years old
column7: the mother of four surviving children
column8: and finally free to leave. She reached New York City in 1829 and joined the Mother AME Zion Church. Known as a preacher and prophet
column9: she spent 14 years in the city before suddenly declaring
column10:
“The Spirit calls me there and I must go.” That day in 1843 she left to travel the land and spread the Lord’s word as Sojourner Truth.

Sojourner Truth traveled throughout New England and as far west as Kansas. When she spoke
column11: everyone listened—even the hecklers. She gave her most famous speech at a women’s rights convention in Ohio. As one there remembered it
column12: the hecklers were hissing but
column13: “At her first word there was a profound hush.” When one man called women “weak
column14: ” Truth looked him in the eye and in her low voice said
column15: “I could work as much and eat as much as a man (when I could get it)
column16: and bear the lash as well -- and ain’t I a woman?” Another time she stopped the hissing with “…we’ll have our rights; see if we don't: and you can’t stop us from them; see if you can. You may hiss as much as you like
column17:
but it is comin’.”

A legend in her own time
column18: Sojourner Truth died in 1883 in Battle Creek
column19:
Michigan. Her funeral was said to be the largest ever seen there.
|While living in New York City
column20:
Isabella Baumfree became Sojourner Truth and left her home at 74 Canal Street to spread the “Lord’s truth.” She became a legend in her own time.

|Born a slave in 1797 in Ulster County
column21: New York
column22: Sojourner Truth spoke out against slavery and injustice
column24:
making people from President Lincoln to street toughs listen.

|1797-12-17 15:29:00|1883-12-17 15:29:00|40.715176|-73.992867|26||26|26|30

column1: 5|st_philip-s_episcopalian_church|St. Philip's Episcopalian Church|The congregation of St. Philip’s has roots that reach back to 1704. That was when Elias Neau
column2: a Frenchman who had himself suffered slavery
column3: opened his home to teach enslaved New Yorkers to read the Bible. Neau was connected to Trinity Church on Wall Street
column4:
and soon Neau’s students began to worship there on Sunday afternoons. Trinity Church was segregated.

As the black worshipers grew frustrated with the church’s refusal to condemn slavery or end the segregation
column5: they began to meet separately
column6: forming the Free African Church of St. Philip. In 1818
column7: skilled carpenters among the group built a small wood church on Centre Street
column8: near Worth.  The church immediately became a center of mutual aid and anti-slavery activities as well as of worship. It grew to become one of the largest black congregations in New York
column9: in spite of fires
column10: racist attacks
column11: and riots. After a fire burned the wooden church
column12: a brick one was built. It survived a riot of 1834
column13: when the church organ
column14: furniture
column15: and much of the building was destroyed by a white mob. It was attacked again during the Civil War Draft Riot
column16:
and the police used St. Philip’s as a barracks for militia and police as they battled thousands of enraged whites for control of the city.

As New York grew and blacks moved north
column17: the church moved
column18: too
column19: first to 25th Street and finally to 134th Street in 1910. There
column20:
St. Philip’s continues its tradition of worship as well as its work for social and economic justice.




|Located at 204 W. 134th Street
column21: the present church building is a New York City Designated Landmark. It was designed by the first African American architect licensed in New York.|St. Philip’s Episcopal Church was a black center for worship
column23: and activism throughout the 1800s. It was located at 31 Centre Street between Worth and Leonard until 1886.|1704-12-17 15:29:00|1886-12-17 15:29:00|40.713734|-74.003448|23||23|23|5

column1: 7|the_gideon_and_the_great_dock|The Gideon and the Great Dock|On an August day in 1664
column2: the Dutch ship Gideon reached the Great Dock in New Amsterdam. Its long journey had begun in the Netherlands
column3: where it took on board wrist and ankle shackles
column4: and other supplies for its mission. Its first stop was Angola
column5: Africa
column6: where the captain was directed to “as quickly as possible
column7: take on board as many slaves as he can conveniently transport
column8: ” along with copper and elephant tusks. The ship then crossed the ocean to the Caribbean
column9: where it delivered slaves and the other “cargo
column10: ” before proceeding to New Amsterdam. It arrived at the Great Dock with 291 Africans. To date
column11: this was the largest shipment of enslaved men
column12: women
column13: and children to the Dutch colony. The Dutch West India Company relied on Africans to build homes
column14: fortifications
column15:
and even the Great Dock. It was Africans who unloaded the Gideon.

Before the Gideon could be loaded again
column16: British warships arrived. Without a single shot being fired
column17: New Amsterdam became New York
column18:
and about 150 Dutch soldiers marched onto the Gideon to sail home.

The English took possession of a town with a population of about 1
column19: 500 whites
column20: 300 slaves
column21: and 75 freedmen. The largest slave owner was the Dutch West India Company
column22: which had granted some of the older Africans a kind of half-freedom and plots of land. The Land of the Blacks was a group of 8-to-12-acre farms north of the town. The English were quick to question the freedom of these blacks and their landholdings. As difficult as life was for the Africans under the Dutch
column23:
it was about to get harsher.
|In 1659
column24: when Africans built the Great Dock
column25: Pearl Street was the water’s edge.  The dock was located between today’s Whitehall Street and Broad Street
column28: arrived at the Great Dock in 1664. Africans did most of the labor needed by the Dutch West India Company in New Amsterdam.|1664-12-17 15:29:00||40.703121|-74.013008|30||30|30|7

column1: 9|the_slave_market|The Slave Market|In 1711
column2: New York was growing quickly
column3: and the growing needs of the city were often supplied by slave labor. Nearly 1
column4: 000 out of about 6
column5: 400 New Yorkers were black
column6: and at least 40 percent of the white households included a slave. In these homes
column7: enslaved workers cooked
column8: washed
column9: sewed
column10: hauled water
column11: emptied the chamber pots
column12: swept out the fireplaces and the chimneys
column13: and cared for the children. Along the East River they built
column14: loaded
column15: and unloaded
column16: the ships. They cleared the land uptown
column17:
and then planted and harvested the crops.  And up and down the narrow streets they pedaled their master’s goods and even supplied the city’s first fast foods—fresh oysters and steaming hot corn on the cob.

As the number of slaves imported into the city soared
column18: barrel makers
column19: butchers
column20: carpenters
column21: blacksmiths
column22: and tin workers began to purchase young enslaved men in order to teach them their trades. Typically
column23: when a slave owner ran out of work
column24:
they hired their slaves out at half the rate of free labor.

Often the slaves themselves were sent out to find work. In a time when fear of a slave uprising was ever-present
column25: the sight of so many enslaved men walking the streets looking to be hired caused alarm. Fearful white citizens began to complain. They demanded a market where slaves could be hired
column30: the City Council passed a law “that all Negro and Indian slaves that are let out to hire…be hired at the Market house at the Wall Street Slip…” This market
column31: known as the Meal Market (because grains were sold there)
column32:
was located at the foot of Wall Street on the East River. It was the city’s first slave market.

|Today
column33: the site of the Slave Market
column34: located at the intersection of Wall Street and Water Street
column35: is far from the water’s edge.|The Slave Market
column36: located where Wall Street reached the East River
column37: was established in 1711 as a place where enslaved blacks and Native Americans could be hired or purchased.|1711-12-17 15:29:00||40.705181|-74.007401|10||10|10|9

column1: 26|the_tappan_brothers|The Tappan Brothers|Lewis and Arthur Tappan were brothers who earned a fortune importing silk from Asia. In 1841
column2: Lewis went on to form the Mercantile Agency. Today it is known as Dun and Bradstreet
column3:
a billion-dollar corporation.

At that time
column4: more and more white New Yorkers were in favor of ending slavery
column5: but very few were for equal rights. The Tappans were different. They demanded “universal liberty.” Whites
column6: such as the Tappans
column7: who spoke out for equality were hated and often targeted. During the riots of 1834
column8: pro-slavery mobs attacked the Tappans repeatedly. First the Chatham Chapel
column9: which the brothers rented for abolitionist meetings
column10: was attacked. The next day Lewis’s home was attacked; his belongings were piled in the street and burned. Then Arthur’s store was attacked—twice. A year later a $100
column11:
000 reward was offered to anyone who delivered the dead bodies of the Tappans to any slave state. The only protection Lewis relied on was the bible in his breast pocket. Both brothers drew on their faith for strength and continued their abolitionist work.

Working with African Americans such as Frederick Douglass
column12: Samuel Cornish
column13: and Henry Highland Garnet
column14: the brothers accomplished many things. They helped found the New York Anti-Slavery Society and were actively part of the Underground Railroad. Lewis organized the defense for the Africans of the slave ship Amistad. The brothers also gave money to integrated colleges
column15: abolitionist newspapers
column16: and many other anti-slavery organizations. Arthur Tappan died in 1865
column17:
the year that the 13th Amendment outlawed slavery. Lewis Tappan died 8 years later.

|The offices of Arthur and Lewis Tappan were located at 122 Pearl Street. When pro-slavery mobs attacked during the riots of 1834
column18: clerks fought them off with firearms.|Arthur and Lewis Tappan were brothers
column19: businessmen
column20: and staunch abolitionists. Because they worked with black leaders for equal rights

column1: 23|the_manhattan_company|The Manhattan Company|The Manhattan Company was formed to bring fresh water to New Yorkers. Or at least that was its stated purpose. What the founders really wanted to do was to open a bank. In the end they did both. The Bank of the Manhattan Company
column2: founded in 1799
column3: was a huge success. Today it is known as JP Morgan Chase. The company’s mission to deliver fresh water to New Yorkers was not as successful
column4:
however.

The city in 1800 reached as far north as Chambers Street. Above that were widely spaced homes and farms along dirt roads. There were also slaughterhouses and places where animal hides were tanned—both very smelly businesses
column5:
located near what was once a supply of good fresh water called the Collect Pond.

The plan was to build a waterworks on Reade Street near the pond and pump the water around the city through a network of log pipes. It was a big job. About 25 miles of pipe had to be laid. The streets were paved with heavy cobblestones
column6: which had to be torn up. Then a deep trench was dug and the hollowed pine logs -- each 13 feet long and 13 inches in diameter -- were laid in the trench and pounded together. Sand and earth were placed back in the trench
column7:
and any leftover dirt was carted away.

The laborers made one dollar a day
column8: but if the worker was enslaved
column9: his or her earnings went to the owner. At that time enslaved men and women were sometimes sent to the Slave Market at the end of Wall Street to hire themselves out. There were many free Africans in the city
column10: too
column11:
but it was harder for them to get good-paying jobs.


|The Manhattan Company’s water system
column12: which never worked very well
column13: was replaced in 1842 when fresh drinking water began to flow into the city from Croton.|Around 1801 workers lay log water pipes along Broad Street as officials from the Manhattan Company look on. The workers laid 25 miles of pipe in the city’s first water system.|1800-12-17 15:29:00||40.7066|-74.009827|25||25|25|23

column1: 11|the_land_of_the_blacks|The Land of the Blacks|In the hills and swamps that stretched across Manhattan Island one mile north of New Amsterdam
column2: both free and enslaved blacks began to clear the tangle of trees
column3: vines
column4: and shrubs to build their own homes and plant their own gardens. The time was 1643
column5:
and the area would soon be called the Land of the Blacks.

The black settlement began during the Dutch wars with neighboring Indians. When raids began
column6: the white settlers fled to the safety of New Amsterdam. Director-General Willem Kieft decided to replace the white settlers with black ones
column7: as a buffer for the community. The first land grants were given to members of the black militia such as Domingo Anthony and “Captain of the Blacks” Manuel Trumpeter
column8: or their widows
column9: such as Catalina Anthony. The grants were sizeable
column10: from eight to twelve acres each
column11: enough land for a garden
column12: crops
column13: and pasture for their cattle
column14: goats
column15: and sheep. Orchards were planted and included trees of apples
column16: peaches
column17: plums
column18:
and cherries.  The homes and barns were mostly wooden with roofs of thatch or board.  

Many of those who gained land grants were elders who had won a status we know as half-freedom
column19: but their children remained enslaved. Nevertheless
column20: the farms were passed down through the generations
column21: creating a strong black community that petitioned for their rights
column24: at least a century before the Underground Railroad
column25: harbored runaways.|Minetta Lane is a remnant of a road
column27: that ran alongside Minetta Creek and connected some of the African farms with New Amsterdam.|The Land of the Blacks included parts of Chinatown
column30: and Greenwich Village. Washington Square Park includes land once owned by five Africans.|1643-12-17 15:29:00||40.730251|-74.001022|27||27|27|11

column1: 20|the_theodore_wright_house|The Theodore Wright House|One day in the mid-1800s
column2: 28 men
column3: women
column4: and children snuck into New York City. They were runaways
column5: escaping slavery on the Underground Railroad. Theodore Wright and his friend Charles Ray spent the day getting food for them
column6: as well as passage on a barge to Albany. From there
column7: all 28 fled to Canada
column8: where they could live free. Wright helped many slaves to freedom
column9: but there are few documents that tell about his work
column10:
since it was illegal.

Theodore Sedgwick Wright was born in 1797 and educated at the African Free School. He went on to become the first black graduate of the Princeton Theological Seminary. Wright was born free
column11: but he hated slavery and did everything in his power to fight it. His home was a station on the Underground Railroad
column12: and he spoke out against slavery from the pulpit of his church on Prince Street. He was a founding member of the American Anti-Slavery Society and president of the New York Committee of Vigilance. To belong to abolitionist societies at that time took courage. During the riots of 1834
column13: white toughs attacked the offices and homes of abolitionists
column14:
breaking and burning everything they could lay their hands on.

As slavery was in the process of being abolished in New York
column15: Wright was one of the first to speak out against racism. At an anti-slavery convention of both white and black delegates
column16: he boldly stated
column17: “It is an easy thing to ask about the vileness of slavery
column18: but to treat the man of color in all circumstances as a man and brother -- that is the test.” Wright died in 1847
column19: as slavery was spreading to the West.|Wright’s home at 235 W. Broadway was part of the Underground Railroad at a time when slave catchers roamed the streets of the city and kidnapped runaways to return them south.|Theodore S. Wright was born free and was well educated
column20: but he risked his own home and well-being every time he helped a runaway reach freedom in Canada.|1797-12-17 15:29:00|1847-12-17 15:29:00|40.719563|-74.00602|16||16|16|20

column1: 32|tontine_coffeehouse|The Tontine Coffeehouse|Across from the Meal Market
column2: where enslaved workers could be hired or bought
column3: was the Tontine Coffee House
column4: home of the New York Stock Exchange. Powerbrokers of the day met in a room there to buy
column5: sell
column6: and trade. As soon as a ship’s captain reached the harbor
column7: this is where he came to register his cargo. The goods coming into New York in the 1790s included coffee
column8: tea
column9: sugar and molasses
column10: fine furniture
column11: cloth
column12: cotton
column13: and enslaved men
column14: women
column15:
and children.

The companies that insured

The slave trade was big business and New Yorkers made huge profits from it long after slavery was made illegal in the state. The first and last New York slave trader to be executed was caught in April 1861

as the first shots of the Civil War were fired.

The New York Stock Exchange has roots that go back to a spring day in 1792

column21: where it remained until 1817. In the words of its president
column22: it was a place “filled with underwriters

column31:
bustle and activity." It was also a place built on slavery.
|In the 1790s
column32: the Tontine Coffee House was only one block from the East River. By 1820
column33: it was 2 blocks from the river as landfill widened Manhattan Island. |In 1792
column34: the New York Stock Exchange was located in the Tontine Coffee House at 82 Wall Street.  Slave ships were registered here and a value was assigned to the Africans on board.|1792-12-18 11:50:00|1817-12-18 11:50:00|40.70548|-74.007793|21||21|21|32

column1: 25|the_african_burial_ground|The African Burial Ground|The AFBG is a federally designated historic landmark and archaeological site that was used as a cemetery by free and enslaved people of African descent during the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries. It’s believed that between 10
column3: 000 people are buried here. The site covers approximately 7 acres and is bounded by Duane Street on the north
column4: Chambers Street on the south
column5: Centre and Lafayette Streets on the east
column6:
and Broadway to the west.

In 1991
column7: archaeological fieldwork began. While excavating a site for a new building at 290 Broadway
column8: construction workers discovered skeletal remains of early Africans. The site was designated a National Historic Landmark in 1993 because of its unprecedented potential to provide information about the lives of early Africans
column9:
including their quality of health and the region of Africa they came from. (One previously unknown fact: The mortality rate for children under 16 years old was 43% based on a sample of 301 individuals buried at the site.) The information gathered by archaeologists and historians significantly altered historical misconceptions about the life and culture of Africans. And burial practices revealed at the site reflected the cultural and religious beliefs of enslaved people that had previously been undocumented -- such as the fact that many of the people buried here had played a significant role in the building of New York City.

Mayor David Dinkins
column10: Lt. Gov. David Patterson
column11: Illinois Congressman Gus Savage
column12: Dr. Michael Blakey
column13:
and a Howard University team of researchers deserve recognition for the key role that they played in preserving this crucial part of African American history.
|The African Burial Ground National Monument memorial is located at Duane and Elk Streets. An exhibit at the visitor center is located at 290 Broadway on the ground floor.|For most of the 1700s
column14: and maybe earlier
column15: Africans and their descendents kept their own burial ground north of the city and its wall. As in Africa

column1: 24|rikers_island|Rikers Island|On March 5
column3: a crowd of over 10
column4: 000 New Yorkers watched in awe as 1
column5: 000 well-disciplined Union army troops left Rikers Island and marched west to the Hudson River
column6:
their dark blue uniforms and crisp white gloves and white leggings glistening in the sunlight.

What made this event so unusual was that the soldiers were black.

The 20th Colored Regiment was formed by the New York Union League
column7: who hoped to present the black troops as part of the New Society that would take place once the South was defeated and the country united. George Bliss
column8: a prominent member of the Union League who later became the U.S. attorney for the southern district of New York City
column9:
led the effort to raise money for the formation of New York’s three black regiments.

The troops received their training at Rikers Island before being sent to Louisiana. The 20th and the 26th Regiments were part of the 7
column10: 500 black soldiers who served the Union cause. These troops were paid less than half of their white counterparts’ salaries
column11: received inferior equipment
column12:
and lived in poor conditions.

Near the end of 1864
column13:
Rikers Island was transformed from a camp where soldiers were sent for temporary duty and training to a prisoner of war facility for Confederate soldiers.

The city of New York purchased the island in 1884 from the Riker family
column14:
who had settled it in 1638. Today it is New York City’s largest jail facility.

247 words|Located in the East River near Long Island Sound
column15: Rikers Island can be reached by bridge from Queens
column16: but it is considered to be part of the Bronx.|In 1864
column17: the 26th Regiment of the U.S. Colored Troops trained on Rikers Island. They went on to fight
column18: along with 180
column19: 000 other black soldiers

column1: 22|the_audubon_ballroom|The Audubon Ballroom|Best known as the place where Malcolm X was assassinated on February 21
column3:
the Audubon Ballroom has long been a center of African American social and political activity.

Located at 3940 Broadway between 165th and 166th Streets in the Washington Heights section of Manhattan
column4: the theater was developed by William Fox
column5:
a Hungarian immigrant who founded the Fox Film Company in 1915.

Designed by Thomas Lamb
column6: one of the leading theater designers of the time
column7: the building’s Broadway façade featured a three-dimensional terra cotta boat with the head of Neptune
column8:
based on the mythical ship Argo of Jason and the Argonauts fame.

The ballroom
column9: located on the 2nd floor
column10: served as a venue for a number of important historical events
column11:
such as the meeting place for the Municipal Transit Workers Union.
It also was the venue for the annual New York Mardis Gras festival
column12:
when a King and Queen of Harlem were crowned.

More recently the site has been controversial because of a plan by the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center
column13: which purchased the property from the city of New York
column14:
to raze it and build a medical research center.

African Americans protested the demolition and a compromise was reached
column15: whereby part of the original building would remain and a memorial to Malcolm X would be created. A statue of Malcolm X now stands in the Broadway lobby. In 1997
column16: David Graves
column17: a California artist
column18:
created a 12-by-63-feet mural to honor Malcolm X’s achievements.
|The site now boasts the Malcolm X and Dr. Betty Shabazz Memorial and Educational Center
column19: where three multi- media kiosks provide the largest exhibit on Malcolm X in the world. |The Audubon Ballroom included a theater as well as meeting halls. Many labor
column20: political
column21: and religious groups met there
